results.headline: Rape and Murder, Precisely Like a Crime Years Ago

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Silence

results.summary_short: “The Silence” begins with the rape and murder of an 11-year-old girl; 23 years later, it happens again in an eerily precise duplicate.

results.headline: Holy Man or Hypocrite? A Low-Risk Devil’s Wager

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Monk

results.summary_short: Based on a Gothic thriller, “The Monk” traces the downfall of a sternly pious monk.

results.headline: 26 Ways to Die Gruesomely

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The ABCs of Death

results.summary_short: Everybody’s got to go sometime in “The A B Cs of Death,” a collection of horror shorts in many languages.

results.headline: That Man, Before the Curtain, and Before Dorothy, Too

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Oz: The Great and Powerful

results.summary_short: “Oz the Great and Powerful,” starring James Franco and Michelle Williams, is Disney’s prequel to the original story.

results.headline: A Blunt Instrument in the Climate War

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Greedy Lying Bastards

results.summary_short: In “Greedy Lying Bastards,” Craig Scott Rosebraugh sets out to kick global-warming-denying corporate keisters.

results.headline: The Power of an Educated Woman

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Girl Rising

results.summary_short: Young women from around the world tell their stories of triumph over adversity in “Girl Rising,” a twist on the social issue documentary.

results.headline: The American General Who Ruled Japan

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Emperor

results.summary_short: In “Emperor,” Tommy Lee Jones plays Gen. Douglas MacArthur during the American occupation of Japan that followed World War II.

results.headline: Young, Pregnant, Gone to Vegas

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Electrick Children

results.summary_short: “Electrick Children,” written and directed by Rebecca Thomas, is a coming-of-age fable about two teenagers from a fundamentalist Mormon family in southern Utah.

results.headline: A Cannery Row in Maine

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Downeast

results.summary_short: Workers for a closed sardine plant in Maine get their hopes up in “Downeast.”

results.headline: Plucked From Obscurity, and Now a Star!

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Don't Stop Believin': Everyman's Journey

results.summary_short: A young Filipino gets to live his Steve Perry dream in “Don’t Stop Believin’: Everyman’s Journey.”

results.headline: Dehumanized Souls Packing Noir Weapons

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dead Man Down

results.summary_short: In “Dead Man Down,” a thug with a secret past squares off with a disfigured woman seeking revenge for an attack.

results.headline: A Longtime Comedian, Still Without a Break

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bitter Buddha

results.summary_short: A ranter with jokes onstage, Eddie Pepitone shows a mellower side at home in “The Bitter Buddha.”

results.headline: Hopelessly Devoted to Himself

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I, Me aur Main

results.summary_short: In “I, Me aur Main,” a Bollywood romance directed by Rakesh Sharma, a vain hunk has a lot to learn from the women in his life.

results.headline: The Devil Wants a Sequel

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Exorcism Part II

results.summary_short: In “The Last Exorcism: Part II,” the victim of the first film in this series is in a house for recovering trauma patients in New Orleans when her demon again comes a-courting.

results.headline: With Friends Like These . . .

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 21 and Over

results.summary_short: “21 & Over,” the directorial debut of the “Hangover” screenwriting team, Jon Lucas and Scott Moore, follows an odd couple through a night of juvenile debauchery.

results.headline: Atrocities, Through a Child’s Eyes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of War Witch

results.summary_short: “War Witch” tells the story of orphaned African children who have been conscripted into a rebel army after their village has been attacked and their parents slain.

results.headline: A Dreamy Drift From Teenage Idylls to Adult Complexities

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pavilion

results.summary_short: In Tim Sutton’s dreamy “Pavilion” a teenage boy leaves his mother’s upstate New York home to live with his father in Arizona, where youth starts to feel even more ephemeral than summer.

results.headline: Finding a Space, and Yourself

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Welcome to Pine Hill

results.summary_short: “Welcome to Pine Hill” is about the different worlds that exist in a modern city (Brooklyn), and even within a single human being.

results.headline: This London Police Unit Will Do Anything

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sweeney

results.summary_short: “The Sweeney” follows Jack Regan, the leader of an elite London police unit whose tactics emulate those of the thugs it pursues.

results.headline: A Struggling Actor and a Struggling Single Dad

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The End of Love

results.summary_short: “The End of Love” follows a struggling Los Angeles actor and dissolute single dad as he faces the responsibilities of raising his toddler.
